papers.title: Attention Is All You Need
papers.abstract: The dominant sequence transduction models are based on complex recurrent or convolutional neural networks that include an encoder and a decoder. The best performing models also connect the encoder and decoder through an attention mechanism. We propose a new simple network architecture, the Transformer, based solely on attention mechanisms, dispensing with recurrence and convolutions entirely.

papers.title: BERT: Pre-training of Deep Bidirectional Transformers for Language Understanding
papers.abstract: We introduce a new language representation model called BERT, which stands for Bidirectional Encoder Representations from Transformers. Unlike recent language representation models, BERT is designed to pre-train deep bidirectional representations from unlabeled text by jointly conditioning on both left and right context in all layers.

papers.title: ImageNet Classification with Deep Convolutional Neural Networks
papers.abstract: We trained a large, deep convolutional neural network to classify the 1.2 million high-resolution images in the ImageNet LSVRC-2010 contest into the 1000 different classes. On the test data, we achieved top-1 and top-5 error rates of 37.5% and 17.0% which is considerably better than the previous state-of-the-art.

papers.title: Deep Residual Learning for Image Recognition
papers.abstract: Deeper neural networks are more difficult to train. We present a residual learning framework to ease the training of networks that are substantially deeper than those used previously. We explicitly reformulate the layers as learning residual functions with reference to the layer inputs, instead of learning unreferenced functions.

papers.title: Generative Adversarial Networks
papers.abstract: We propose a new framework for estimating generative models via an adversarial process, in which we simultaneously train two models: a generative model G that captures the data distribution, and a discriminative model D that estimates the probability that a sample came from the training data rather than G.

papers.title: CRISPR-Cas9 gene editing in human cells
papers.abstract: Genome engineering technologies based on the CRISPR-associated protein 9 (Cas9) nuclease from Streptococcus pyogenes enable rapid and efficient modification of endogenous genes in mammalian cells. We demonstrate that CRISPR-Cas9-mediated gene editing can be used to introduce both small and large modifications to endogenous genes in human cells.

papers.title: Reinforcement Learning: An Introduction
papers.abstract: Reinforcement learning is learning what to do—how to map situations to actions—so as to maximize a numerical reward signal. The learner is not told which actions to take, but instead must discover which actions yield the most reward by trying them.

papers.title: A survey of deep learning techniques for neural machine translation
papers.abstract: Neural machine translation (NMT) has achieved remarkable results in recent years. In this survey, we provide a comprehensive overview of the recent advances in NMT, including attention mechanisms, copy mechanisms, and coverage mechanisms.
